content: The "Congressional Accountability Now Act" or the "CAN Act" prohibits the use of funds for official travel expenses of Members of Congress and legislative branch employees for airline accommodations other than coach-class. The "Congressional Accountability Now Act" prohibits the use of funds for official travel expenses of Members of Congress and legislative branch employees for airline accommodations other than coach-class, with exceptions outlined in the Act. The "Congressional Accountability Now Act" restricts the use of funds for official travel expenses of Members of Congress and legislative branch employees to coach-class accommodations, with defined exceptions. The Act also provides definitions for coach-class accommodations and Members of Congress. The "Congressional Accountability Now Act" prohibits the use of funds for long-term vehicle leases by Members of Congress and restricts the use of franking privileges by Members of the House of Representatives. SEC. 4 amends Section 311(e) of the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1991 to restrict the use of official mail funds for Members of the House of Representatives. The Congressional Accountability Now Act amends the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 to equalize the annual pay rates for various positions in Congress after a general election. The Congressional Accountability Now Act amends the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 to equalize annual pay rates for positions in Congress after a general election, effective on the first regularly scheduled general election for Federal office after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. TERMINATION OF CERTAIN RETIREMENT BENEFITS FOR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Amendments to the Civil Service Retirement System include the termination of retirement coverage for Members of Congress, with no further contributions or deductions allowed. This does not affect any prior rights. The termination of retirement coverage for Members of Congress does not nullify any prior rights. Members remain eligible to participate in the Thrift Savings Plan. Regulations for this section may be prescribed by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. The term 'Member' excludes the Vice President. Members of Congress can opt-in to remain subject to retirement coverage within 90 days of the enactment of this section.
